RT @SpencerJCox: Hey friends, first some good news: Utah is now 5th in the nation in testing per capita! Unfortunately like many states weâ€¦
This will be effective immediately. Those who are currently in @ZionNational will have the rest of today to leave, and the park will be closed starting tomorrow morning.

Today, after consultation with Washington County officials and the @Interior, we have determined it is appropriate and necessary to close @ZionNational Park, until we decide we can lift the #StaySafe, #StayHome directive.
I have directed that @UtahStateParks be reserved for the residents of the county in which those parks are located. Do not attempt to visit parks outside your county of residence.
If your primary residence is on the Wasatch Front and you are traveling to Washington County to gather with extended family members for a recreational weekend, turn around and go home.

Acceptable reasons to leave home include going to work, or getting necessary supplies, like food or medication.

Outdoor recreation is fine, but NOT in groups, and only if appropriate social distancing is maintained.

Do not travel except for essential services.

Do not hang out in groups, inside or outside.

Only leave home if you have to, and do so as little as possible.

Sunday dinners (or dinner parties on any day of the week) with family or friends from outside your household are off the table. Students who are home from college should NOT treat this like an early summer vacation.

Do not play volleyball with friends at your apartment complex. Do not meet friends for a pick-up basketball game. 

Even small group gatherings are dangerous.
Only people who are living under the same roof should be under the same roof or spend time together. Period.

Do not spend free time with people outside of your immediate household.

Do not have visitors in your home â€” even members of your extended family.
Let me be clear about what is expected and required of us all, if we want to slow the spread of COVID-19.

To slow the spread of the pandemic, we MUST live differently. Many are carefully complying with the #StaySafe, #StayHome directive. Many others, however, might believe that they are obeying the directive, while making convenient exceptions here and there.
@UtahCoronavirus @UtahStateParks @Interior @ZionNPS @UtahStateParks are closed to non-county residents. You may still visit state parks in your own county.

If you have COVID-19 concerns or think you need a test, first, stay home. Use online resources or call 800-456-7707. For moderate to severe symptoms, find a testing facility in your community. Visit https://t.co/OHttfLOuBd for more info. #StayHome

@pretzlekay No. Businesses can remain open, following strict hygiene procedures and social distancing. Businesses should allow employees to telework wherever possible.
Employers: DO NOT require doctor's notes from your employees. If they call in sick with symptoms, or have a family member sick with symptoms, make accommodations for them to stay home. #togetherutah
State parks are only available to residents of the county where the park is located.
You can go outside to exercise and get fresh air â€” but do not congregate at trailheads or at parks. Maintain cautious social distancing, even when you are outside.
Together, we can #flatten the curve, reduce the strain on hospitals and the healthcare system, and minimize the impact on medical resources for those with highest need. #TogetherUtah

At-risk individuals (those who are 60 or older, or have a serious underlying condition) should take special care to leave home as little as possible.
Only leave home when you need to. This includes necessary trips like to your workplace, or to obtain food, medicine, or other medical care.
Do not visit friends or family, or hold group gatherings (except for people living in the same household).
We are all in this together. I expect all Utahns to do this part to slow the spread of coronavirus. This means staying home whenever possible.

We are in the throes of a very challenging time. All of us are making difficult adjustments, some big, and some small, to our daily lives. Today I'm issuing a "Stay Safe, Stay Home" directive to all Utahns.

Our goal is to slow the spread of coronavirus. I'm grateful for the steps each of you take to help this effort, and to take care of each other. We will get through this together. #OneUtah

In this day and age, we have many ways to communicate without face-to-face contact. Please check on your neighbors and family members, and do what you can to help those who are self isolating. #OneUtah
If someone in your home tests positive for COVID-19, everyone in your household should self isolate. This will greatly slow how quickly the virus spreads.
Individuals over 60, or who are immunocompromised, should avoid contact with others.
Individuals should not visit nursing or long-term care facilities, except to provide critical care.
In accordance with recommendations @POTUS made on Monday, March 16, the order also prohibits gatherings of more than ten people.
The order also issues additional instructions to restaurants â€” to add sanitation precautions and check employees for symptoms of COVID-19 at the beginning of each shift.
Social distancing is one of the most important things we can do to slow the spread of COVID-19. Todayâ€™s order is focused on that.
Utah solutions will be a big part of increasing our testing operations. Until we can test widely, we need to take every necessary precaution to slow the spread of coronavirus.
We also have a full-time team focusing on increasing Utahâ€™s capacity to test for COVID-19. We're working on getting more tests, and more chemicals to process those tests.

In making these decisions, we still strongly recommend that Utahns buy local, eat local, and support local businesses at this time, in whatever way they can, and within these guidelines. Our local restaurants are great sources of nutritious, secure, and delicious meals.

We have not made this decision lightly. I know this will disrupt lives and cost jobs, and for that Iâ€™m very sorry. Still, Iâ€™m convinced this will save many lives, and Iâ€™m also convinced that Utahns will step up to help each other, and weâ€™ll get through this together. #OneUtah
With the increasing number of COVID-19 cases in our communities, we must take quick action to adjust and adapt in our daily lives to limit the spread of the virus.

Restaurants can continue curbside, drive-thru, pick up, and delivery options. The order is intended to limit the spread of novel coronavirus in public spaces. This is effective on Wednesday, March 18 at 11:59 p.m.

These recommendations will remain in effect for two weeks. We will continue assessing to determine whether we should continue these measures, expand on them, or pull back after the end of the two-week period.

In addition, I am asking Local Health Departments to protect high-risk populations by requiring long-term care and other care facilities to restrict access and monitor employees and visitors for symptoms of COVID-19.
If you can work from home, start doing so immediately. We applaud all businesses who can take steps to help their employees work from home, and we encourage more to do so.
Everyone over the age of 60 should avoid large gatherings with more than 20 people. Everyone who is immunocompromised should avoid large gatherings with more than 20 people.
This does not apply to schools. Schools are coordinating with their local health officer to assess the situation on a case-by-case basis.

Limiting mass gatherings to groups of 100 for the next two weeks beginning Monday, March 16â€” and that is 100 healthy individuals. This includes church gatherings, concerts, conferences, and similar events.

4) On that note, the spread of this illness will not affect our water supply â€” so stocking up on bottled water (while a good general emergency preparedness tip) does not need to be a priority.

3) Make a plan for if you or someone in your family needs to stay home for a few weeks. This could include getting some extra food supplies in your pantry, or a supply of prescription medications you are currently taking.

2) Prevent the spread of all illnesses with common sense measures like washing your hands often, covering your coughs and sneezes (but not with your hands), disinfecting frequently touched objects, and avoiding touching your eyes, nose and mouth.
1) Take basic steps to support your immune system â€” get enough sleep, eat nutritious food, stay physically active, and manage your stress.
